prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our proposed observation is a single-continuum in each band, integrated in the band width of about 8 GHz.

The target is a point source, thus we do not have any preference on the antenna configuration. 0.7 arcsec will be sufficient to resolve the target from the background. Indeed, we expect that there is no strong background contamination. Possible thermal dust emission from unrelated background or associated molecular clouds is estimated to be negligible; even for the conservative angular resolution of 0.7'' and the source distance of 10 Mpc, these background will be at most 0.02 mJy in Band 7 and much smaller in the other bands. In addition, the multi-epoch observation will allow to distinguish the time-varying target from a static background emission. Any hot dust possibly associated with an SN will have too high temperature and too small mass to contribute to the mm/sub-mm emission.

Here is the sensitivity we request in Band 3 in a single epoch. The same set-up will be used in all the three epochs. Our target is time-variable to be observed in three epochs. Upon our ToO target selection, the criteria are set so that the expected flux in Band 3 is > 0.2 mJy in the last epoch, i.e., the faintest in the evolution. Also, there is a chance that our target is brighter than this limit for our ToO trigger.
The continuum bands are selected in a way to avoid a contamination from possible CO emission lines from underlying star-forming region.

Covering time evolution is a key in our program to follow-up a time-varing transient, and we propose to perform the observations at three epochs. This is a ToO program, and the ToO trigger criteria are described in SJ. The ditribution of the three epochs is described below, which is optimized to reach to the science goal we propose.
The ToO trigger aims at observing the target within the first month after the explosion, namely (roughly) within two or three weeks after the trigger. Then another two epochs separated by about 3 weeks each. As long as the time coordinate roughly follows this basic scheme, we do not require observations in narrow time-windows, thus each observation within an interval of +- 7 days is acceptable.
Our proposed observation is a single-continuum in each band, integrated in the band width of about 8 GHz.

The target is a point source, thus we do not have any preference on the antenna configuration. 0.7 arcsec will be sufficient to resolve the target from the background. Indeed, we expect that there is no strong background contamination. Possible thermal dust emission from unrelated background or associated molecular clouds is estimated to be negligible; even for the conservative angular resolution of 0.7'' and the source distance of 10 Mpc, these background will be at most 0.02 mJy in Band 7 and much smaller in the other bands. In addition, the multi-epoch observation will allow to distinguish the time-varying target from a static background emission. Any hot dust possibly associated with an SN will have too high temperature and too small mass to contribute to the mm/sub-mm emission.

Here is the sensitivity we request in Band 6 in a single epoch. The same set-up will be used in all the three epochs. Our target is time-variable to be observed in three epochs. Upon our ToO target selection, the criteria are set so that the expected flux in Band 6 is > 0.12 mJy in the last epoch, i.e., the faintest in the evolution. Also, there is a chance that our target is brighter than this limit for our ToO trigger.
The continuum bands are selected in a way to avoid a contamination from possible CO emission lines from underlying star-forming region.

Covering time evolution is a key in our program to follow-up a time-varing transient, and we propose to perform the observations at three epochs. This is a ToO program, and the ToO trigger criteria are described in SJ. The ditribution of the three epochs is described below, which is optimized to reach to the science goal we propose.
The ToO trigger aims at observing the target within the first month after the explosion, namely (roughly) within two or three weeks after the trigger. Then another two epochs separated by about 3 weeks each. As long as the time coordinate roughly follows this basic scheme, we do not require observations in narrow time-windows, thus each observation within an interval of +- 7 days is acceptable.
Our proposed observation is a single-continuum in each band, integrated in the band width of about 8 GHz.

The target is a point source, thus we do not have any preference on the antenna configuration. 0.7 arcsec will be sufficient to resolve the target from the background. Indeed, we expect that there is no strong background contamination. Possible thermal dust emission from unrelated background or associated molecular clouds is estimated to be negligible; even for the conservative angular resolution of 0.7'' and the source distance of 10 Mpc, these background will be at most 0.02 mJy in Band 7 and much smaller in the other bands. In addition, the multi-epoch observation will allow to distinguish the time-varying target from a static background emission. Any hot dust possibly associated with an SN will have too high temperature and too small mass to contribute to the mm/sub-mm emission.

Here is the sensitivity we request in Band 7 in a single epoch. The same set-up will be used in all the three epochs. Our target is time-variable to be observed in three epochs. Upon our ToO target selection, the criteria are set so that the expected flux in Band 7 is > 0.1 mJy in the last epoch, i.e., the faintest in the evolution. Also, there is a chance that our target is brighter than this limit for our ToO trigger. Therefore, we expect that the resulting S/N ratio is likely better than described here with our setup.
The continuum bands are selected in a way to avoid a contamination from possible CO emission lines from underlying star-forming region.

Covering time evolution is a key in our program to follow-up a time-varing transient, and we propose to perform the observations at three epochs. This is a ToO program, and the ToO trigger criteria are described in SJ. The ditribution of the three epochs is described below, which is optimized to reach to the science goal we propose.
The ToO trigger aims at observing the target within the first month after the explosion, namely (roughly) within two or three weeks after the trigger. Then another two epochs separated by about 3 weeks each. As long as the time coordinate roughly follows this basic scheme, we do not require observations in narrow time-windows, thus each observation within an interval of +- 7 days is acceptable.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ToO observations of nearby supernovae (SNe) at Band 3, 6, and 7 in three epochs. A main goal is to constrain the electron acceleration mechanism at a shock wave. The {\em mm/sub-mm} emission from young SNe reflects the relativistic electron population at the energy of ~100 to 500 MeV, which has been unexplored in similar environments (SNe and SN remnants). This energy range is exactly the place where we expect to see a transition from inefficient to efficient acceleration in the standard theory of the particle acceleration. The ALMA data will also be used to address physical properties of SNe, e.g., the shock velocity and the circumstellar density connected to the explosion mechanism and progenitor evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00584.T, Probing Electron Acceleration Mechanism in Nearby Core-Collapse Supernovae, Keiichi Maeda
